div.p: IGNORAMUS HIS CONVICTION: SHEWING The necessity and excellency of frequent Hearing and Preaching the sacred Word of GOD.

Written by one who is a hater of Schisme, and humble supplyant at the Throne of Grace, for the perfecting of a right Reformation, answerable to the Word of God, and agreeable to the holy and godly conversations of the righteous.

q.p: For both Prophet and Priests are prophane, yea, in my house have I found their wickednesse, saith the Lord.
Preach the Word, be instant in season, out of season, reprove, rebuke, exhort with all long suffering and Doctrine.
The steps of a good man are ordered by the Lord, and he delighteth in his way.

div.p: Very necessary for all sort of people to reade. in these sad and worfull times.
Imprimatur
LONDON, Printed for R. L. Anno Dom. 1648.

div.head: IGNORAMVS CONVICTION.
div.p: BEfore God of late of his Infinite Mercie was seen in the Mount of our Extreamities, turning our now Captivitie (in some sort) as rivers in the South, leaping by the mountaines, and skipping by the hills of our sinnes, flying upon the wings of the winde for our Beleefe; in so wonderfull a manner, as praised be his Name, now appeares. Many Engines were used by all appearance, to subvert and overthrow, the Liberties both of this Church and State; whilst the sonnes of Beliall (Satans Instruments) left no meanes un-attempted, whereby they might both openly assault, and (failling that) privately undermine and roote out the Power and life of godlinesse, yea, even under shew of love ayming at the overthrow of Religion, under pretence of freindship and brotherly love: as Jacob in the death of Abner.

In ayming to effect so strong a designe (as appeareth since was then in some of their heads) this in show was a strong Catholicon Ingredient, in their secret Counsells, so far as they might or were in hope to Prevaile with any; That Poporde was no Idolatri • : by which maxime received, they poysoned the seat of Judgement, Understanding and Reason, so making way unto their Intentious. Iust Ieroboams Policie, which God scourged with the overthrow of him and his posteritie: for sure his Calfes worship, was by God himself both so pronounced and punished in him and his. And I hope any reasonable men may suppose, that their is the same Idolatrie, If not greater, in falling down before a peece of bread, then was in worshiping a living Calfe which the Egyptians Adored, and in Imitation whereof, both Jeroboam, and the Israelits before him made their golden Calfes, for which they suffered their severall punishments.

For manie, yeares together holy Ministers first were disgraced, discountenanced, suppressed, Imprisonned, occasionally, they their wives and children, starved and famished, for any reliefe they had from them, and their benifices sequestred, for not subscription unto catching cruell Articles of their own Invention, made to entrap, ensnare, keepe forth and thrust forth, conscionable and holy Ministers out of their livings and habitations, this way to their power, dishartning, over-awing and keeping down, the vigorou • spirits of Professors of the power of practicall Religion, therewith strengthing the enemies thereof, heaping up there with and dispersing all the Infamous
scandalls and lies which possibly subtiltie and malice could invent against all those most conscionable of their wayes.

Secondly, such men were onely put in entrusted for the most to preach at Court▪ Pauls, with all such open places before Authoritie and multitudes, as would Cry down Preaching and Exalt Prayer (strict helpers to one another) and what Prayers? Common Prayer I warrant you (their then Diana) for Pulpit Sermon prayers suffered and were tortured with preaching it self, and the frequency thereof. And herein those men entrusted to preach openly & before Authority; all ways choosed some such Texts wherein they jerked both thestrictness of Religion it selfs ralled at its best Preachers, condemning all of them as factious seditious men, perturbers of the State, & withstanders of Authority, because they would not, durst not, or could not in Conscience, subscribe and yeild unto their Fooleries and Ceremonies. Though otherwise • cry quiet peaceable men, and peacemakers, rather then sowers of disspentions and divisions, like manie now amongst us. But then with those men in the height of their way, no Holinesse was notified in any, saving Sub
• cription and Common Prayer Pietie: whereby they aymed in time to purge he Church of these disturbing Puritans, which noble Nickname, they in great contempt and derision gave them, hoping within a while to rid this Kingdome of them all.

But this Course not prevailing, and Religions Pietie like the people of God in Egypt, the more they were troden upon, like the Cammomile, mounting, growing and prospering so much the more: a course was taken to keepe out all holy and good men from the Ministery, and government of the Church, and let in onely such as would advance their endes into all dignities and spirituall preferments of any worth, having a Role of their favourites names ready who should succeed, in the vacancie of any livings of worth: kept by their grand Captaine, so that it was usually knowne and noied in •… ny preferments who should next succeed. So that by this meanes Cruell •… nd Prophane men, (Arm • nians at best) dropt into all livings, such who would be sure to keep down, discountenance, and undermine the life of pie
•… e, being as prickles and thornes in the sides of all good men: whereby in this •… me, in their Judgement a good progresse was made, both for their Inten
•… d P • ojects against the power of godlinesse, with advancement of Super
•… tion and Atheisme: Properies two grand ushers: though some good men •… ere now and then put in, to sylemens eyes from looking which way the •… rea • e of their Current run.

T • n • s thus drawing towards a head, now the glorie of former banish
•… and removed Altars must up againe. The former wisedome of this State
in displacing them were accounted Ignoramusis, not knowing how to place them, they must again stand up mounting steps for perspecuity, as they did of old Alter-ways, men must now bow before them, with strict Injunction also to bow at the Name of Jesus, and yet to good men in snares whom otherwayes they knew not how to Intrap, for adorning of disgraced degraded Copes, their must be an after service, performed at both ends of the Altar, with low bowing at their approach unto it: apparelled for feare of colde, with gaudie Copes. Whereunto (save the pleasure of Authoritie) it had beene much better, to have used them like that menstruous Cloth spoken of by the Prophet, saying unto them with abomination, get thee hence. Thus insensibly under shew of Order did some of them make way unto all confusion: that so as some of them have pleaded, though they had no Intention to bring in Poperie, yet Poperie (more bold then welcome) having recovered Illimited courage and strength, might forcibly either thrust in it selfe wholly, or else for quietnesse or peace sake enforce a Toleration with us by Power, untill it might in time wholy dispossesse us at its pleasure. To which purpose often and frequent Masses, in many corners of Popish Chappells and liberties were allowed, with as full and free concours unto them as unto our Se • mōs, by many thousands every morning.

But all these not sufficiently to their mindes prevailing so long as after noone Sermons were a foot which revived and quickned the life of grace, advancing pietie and undermining all their designes, a course was taken, so to suppresse preaching and the power of pietie, and entrap the best men in further snares, whom otherwise by their unconformitie they could not suppresse, and who opposed their enormities. Which course of theirs, it pleased God, being universally murmured at, and cryed out against, neither prospered nor lasted long, any where, save where some of their rotten Instruments, exercised their Tyrannick power, Lording it to some purpose, so far as one of them wrote a triumphant▪ if not an infamous letter unto one of the Brotherhood, (boasting of Impietie) That praised be God, That weeke past their had not been one after noone Sermon in all his Diocesse. O fearfull! No wonder then, when the hearts of these men began to be so Impious, as to glory of their shame, and boast of mischiefe, that it was a sure foreru • ner of ruine, because as before destruction the heart of man is haughty, so humility, is a sure usher unto Honour. By all which it appeared, that conformity to Ceremonies, (though they veiled their other purposes therewith) was not that they aymed at: but to root out the life and Power of Pietie, that at length Popery might by force jus • le in it selfe, and at length as formerly Command all.

And wonder it was, that when the Lord commands to preach the word i • season and out of season, and to be instant: this being Heavens high read to advance pietie, encrease faith, and beautifie the glorious strength of the New Creature: that yet those Ignoramuses, would take this open course against Religion in the face of Heaven and Earth to be so bold and Impudent, as to endeavour to overthrow all? But no wonder it was, when all of them were ruled by one or a few, who had it seemed so strictly besieged all Religious strongest holds and forts, that all went wrong; endeavouring to poyson the Fountaines of Authority, so to wind all, that they did what they listed: and so Religion had extreamly suffered, had not God been seen in the Mount of our extreamities, infatuating and taking (as usually his custome is) such men to fall by their own counsells. Whereby now the whole Body of Episcopacy, with all theirs, are in danger to suffer, though their were then amongst them, many holy learned, mercifull, pious, discreet and wise men, free from the death of the Councels devices▪ and imaginations of these ringleaders▪ wishing things might have been carried to have runne in a more smooth and milde current. For which cause a late Bishop of that fraternity, condoling their estat •• : thus wrote to one of the fraternity, his feare, least one mans fierce violence, would undoe them all: who now are all in danger to suffer and smart with the worser sort. In having too much connived with them in countenancing their actions, in notwithstanding their oppressions and exorbitancies, in not timely diswading them from their violent courses, having served them in divers uses, in bearing pressures and burden • of their imposing, and in some things in serving their unjustnesse. And in not removing the causes of such oppressions, the snares and devices to catch and intrap good men, for so many yeares together lapt up in these late Remaining Ceremonies.

And truely, it appeares that these famous worthies who first reformed this Church, (some of them after that proving Martyr-Bishops) when they left these Ceremonies lately in the Church, doing a way others, never thought or imagined either to have retained them so long, or that they should have beene made snares or baits to catch good Ministers in, keepe out some, put others forth, and worser in their places, and to have proved the causes of so many fierce contentions and oppositions for so many yeares since.

For in that Preface unto their Service Booke: Authorized by King Edward the Sixth, they to this purpose write. We have not in abolishing of other Ceremonies and leaving of these, done the same for any holinesse, worth, or use, we have or imagine to make of them, more then of the residue abolished; or for any purpose we have still to reteine the same, but in time to do • those away also.
Onely because we would not too soon dete • the people, by abbrogating of all sh • w 〈◊〉 of the former Service in the Masse; to wind them to Religion by degrees, we therefore have left these few Ceremonies, to make some shew of the former service, having in substance purged and taken away the grosse superstitions, that they might the sooner be woond to like of the Reformation made: not to be out of love with Religion before they know it; having some shewes and shadowes of the former Service; these Ceremonies in time also to be removed.

But what hast their successors have made in this kinde to have removed these offending stumbling blockes, is evidently knowne, most apparant and wofull; in that they have not onely retained, but also abused those Ceremonies unto the hurt of others, urging them with such heate of sevexity (usque ad Ara • ) yea as Divine Oracles, making of others suffer for not conforming unto them: having also added more unto these, as though, Their litle finger should be heavier then their predecessors whole hand, and all this under pretence of Unity, Conformity, and Order: a wofull Unity, Order and Conformity, that now hath bred, and been the Author of so much confusion, destruction, and disorder: so as now the Power of godlinesse and life of grace in pure preaching, hath been in danger to have been overthrown, whilest for many yeares together, Publike Service strove and strugled to cry down Preaching, and exalt Prayer (as they said) as though they were not both exact h • lpers to one another, as hath been touched, by their crying down of after noon Sermons.

Wherein so blockish were some of them as to restraine Preaching under pretext, That one Sermon a day was enough, and more then any man could practise in many yeares together: the Refutation of which grosse errour, produced now this short discourse, to shew, both the excellency and necessity of often Hearing and Preaching: and to confute these prophane Ignor amuses.

A wonder it is, that for the supportation of the life of grace, in that which shrould cherish the Immortall soule, in its wonderfull actings, To Fore see, pevent, gathertogether, multiply, survey, conclude, invent, purpose, dispute, discourse, choose, refuse, resolve, judge and determine of all things Rationally, dwelling in the darke Prison of a lumpish Body (good for nothing without it) where it hath so manie hinderances and lets, besides its naturall depravation untill Illuminated that heereunto they are contented to allow only one meale a weake and day; when they can allow the body constantly two meales sometimes three every day, not understanding, The ends, right use and causes, of often and freequent Preaching and Hearing, which are Three, and wherewith I will conclude.

First for Conversion, in which case, untill Illumination, we are just like unto that impotent man, who lay so long at the poole of Bethesda, waiting when the Spirit of grace, will so blow by some of the Angel Ministers, as that we may be Converted. In which case what is not, to day, this weeke,
weeks, a moneth, moneths, a yeare, yeares, yea in many yeares effected: yet may come to passe at length: so as men must wait still, when the winde of he Spirit will blow with the means, and so trouble the muddy waters of our corruptions, (throwing us into the Poole of Regeneration) as Conversion may be wrought. For which cause hearers must waite, and heare the word in season and out of season, as Ministers are bound to Preach the same: And the more the better, untill Christ by the Newbirth, may see of the travell of his soule and be satisfied: that he thereby be formed in them.

Secondly, being Newborne, we must not now stand still, but grow in grace and in the knowledge of our Lord Jesus Christ, from faith to faith, and grace to grace, untill we come unto a perfect man in Christ, in the beauty of the New Creature: to be built up in that riches of understanding spoken of, so to put on the Lord Jesus in all his holy vertues, being transformed into his Image from glory to glory, to be as like him as may be. For this cause also, the word cannot be to often and frequently preached and Heard, both in season and out of season, to be built up daily more and more in Heavenly knowledge unto life everlasting, to be fully Sanctified and endowed with a great deal of grace here, that thereby we may be so much the fitter vessells, prepared for so much the more glory.

And Thirdly, our fraile house of Clay &c. Wherein the Immortall soule hath its habitation here, the life of grace thereof must still be kept in reparation: we have backslidings, and are to encounter with many temptations. Troubles, Vexations, Discouragements, having many Spirituall diseases to be cured: as Satan is cunning to assualt us full of trouble. And also the soule is to be kept in Spirituall life, courage and vigour, which not one or many dayes hearing can effect: to make up the every day miseries of our life renewed from day to day which we are sure and forced to encounter with. This daily and often Preaching effects, to Cure, Mitigate, Answer, and heale daily, all our Spirituall diseases and doubtings, quickning our dulnesse to helpe the life of Faith, encrease, maintaine, and renew our comforts, to keepe them alwaies upon the winge as it were, to cheere, encourage and harten us on in our Spirituall Journey homewards. So that having so many enemies, difficulties, temptations and troubles, to encounter with from the world, the flesh and the Devill: and the surmountingly glorious fabrique of of the New Creature to erect and build up as neere as may be in its beauty, Excellency and Eminency; we cannot upon all occasions, either heare too much or too often, neither (as some think) can their be too much Preaching, which by the assistance and push of the Spirit, during all our life time, and daily, hath all these and many more wonders to worke: all which I hope willbe sufficient for Ignoramu's Conviction.
